instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.3V3_S0: What is 3V3_S0? Abbreviation for PP3V3_S0, a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> 1.7v
threads.message:
Liquid damage in <CHIP>U5400</CHIP> area and above smc, replaced <CHIP>U5400</CHIP> and <CHIP>U5600</CHIP> as they had no legs
replaced <RESISTOR>R5499</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R5498</RESISTOR>

Green light to orange, pp5v are all good but the last 3v3 rail only measures 1.7v and no short to gnd on it.
Board is getting a little warm near the thunderbolt port area

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> 1.7v
threads.message:
Compare diode mode to ground with an working board.

Lot of components connected to <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0_ISNS</SIGNAL>.
Some of them can be isolated, removing a resistor, or coil.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> 1.7v
threads.message: diode mode same for working board

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> 1.7v
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> 1.7v
threads.message:
So the problem was in <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0_FET</SIGNAL> line???
Next time, post accurate information...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> 1.7v
threads.message: it was with <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL>..., i traced it back and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0_FET</SIGNAL> is what becomes <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> no?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> 1.7v
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> 1.7v
threads.message: thats what I saw too but my brd doesnt have a ISNS  rail, but fet is connected to <SIGNAL>3V3_S0</SIGNAL> through <RESISTOR>R5520</RESISTOR> pin 1 and 2

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> 1.7v
threads.message:
So many <SIGNAL>3V3_S0</SIGNAL> lines there; I wasn't sure which one you've reffered.
I can only give a generic reply, in such case.
However, good to heard is solved now.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> 1.7v
threads.message: Thank you, I'll try be more descriptive next
